Rich Summative Task
Social Infographic

item.description:
HSB4U

Task: Infographic about a social issue

Type of Assessment: Culminating Task (RST)

Purpose of Assessment: Assessment OF Learning

Method of Assessment: KTCA Four Level +/-

Learning Goals:

Ontario Curriculum Expectations

A3

assess, record, analyse, and synthesize information gathered through research and inquiry

A3.1

assess various aspects of information gathered from primary and secondary sources (e.g., accuracy, relevance, reliability, inherent values and bias, voice) 

B2. 

demonstrate an understanding of the causes and effects of social change;

B2.1 

describe ways in which influential Canadian leaders have contributed to social change (e.g., Nellie McClung, Agnes Macphail, Tommy Douglas, Lester B. Pearson, Pierre Trudeau, David Suzuki, Phil Fontaine, Roberta Jamieson, Adrienne Clarkson)

B2.2

explain how various economic, environmental, political, or sociocultural factors (e.g., global warming/climate change, environmental activism, the threat of separatism, leadership changes, pluralism) can lead to social change, and how other factors (e.g., cost, traditional values, fear of negative consequences) can create resistance to change

B2.3 

explain various means of creating social change (e.g., direct action, protest, advocacy, community organization, revolution, political activism) 

C3

demonstrate an understanding of social science theories about social deviance, and of how various responses to deviance affect individuals and society

C3.1

describe the key ideas of major social science theories related to deviance (e.g., labelling theory, social control theory, differential association theory, cultural theories)

C3.2

summarize and interpret statistics related to social deviance, discrimination, and hate crimes

C3.3

describe various methods of deterrence used within local, national, and global institutions

and societies

C3.4

explain the relationship between social panic about crime and deviance and the attention given to these issues by media, politicians, and other social groups



Instructions:

Step One: BRAINSTORMING

Type of Assessment: Culminating Task (RST)

Purpose of Assessment: Assessment of Learning

1. Choose any social issue you would want to study. 

2. Incorporate your chosen social issue to the topics we have discussed. How do you think are they related or interconnected?

Step Two: Outline your goals in creating your infographic

Your infographic should address or solve any social issue and make sure to connect it to a theory, concept, philosophies that we have discussed in our class. 

Your outline should depend on how you plan to present the information you have gathered. It could be a presentation of two opposing sides, the interconnection of concepts to each other, or a flow chart of a concept.

Step Three: Collect Data for Infographic

You may search for databases, numerical data, or articles to support your infographics. 

Step Four: Visualize the data

Choose the best chart for your purpose. If you want to inform, you may use pictograph, flowchart, donut chart. If you want to compare, try bar, pie, or stacked column charts. If you want to present change, you may use timeline or line chart. 

Step Five: Add style to your infographic design

You may use website or applications like photoshop, canva, or even as microsoft word. Experiment with using different colors, icons, fonts, and pictures. Make sure that your infographic is readable and appealing to your reader. Remember that the goal of infographics is to make an appealing presentation of an idea. 

Step six: Write your data

The infographics should have:

1. A problem or question needs to be addressed.

2. A social issue

3. Application of the concepts/theories you learned in class. 

4. Incorporate your opinion to your presentation. 

5. Simplified and comprehensible presentation of your ideas. 

6. Use MLA format in citing your references. 

Step seven: Review your work

Read through your infographics before submitting it for marking. Use the rubric provided by your teacher as a guide in editing and finalizing your proposal.

Step eight: SUBMIT

Submit your copy of the homework document and your final research proposal in your shared course folder.
